ellipses is coming right now depending on word after each space between words -> if the next word is too long then it would pass it to next line and if it's already the 2nd line then would just end up with ... on the last word before space.
what do you think about text-overflow: hidden?
or clip

and text-overflow:clip would not allow us to end with ...
that is what I'm suggesting... to not have ...

Hmm, a couple of thoughts:

  1. I do think we need some indication that there might be more names on the list if they are cut off. We might be able to get away with .. rather than ... if we want to save space.
  2. I think we should keep the current algorithm of showing as much of the name as we can, even if it's not a full word:
    Screen-Shot-2022-02-10-at-8.45.21-AM.png

Jai soni in general, if your prototype differs from the current implementation in ways that are not requested on the issue, it is very helpful if you can identify this and point out the differences, rather than the reviewer needing to find them. So, in this case, since the issue specified giving PMs two lines, but your PR also changes how names are abbreviated, it would be great to call that out.

umm, a genral point of basic English for the idea of 2 dots.. >

An ellipsis (…) is used to denote that something is being left out of the sentence in formal writing, or someone’s voice or thought that is fading in informal writing. The two dots are used by people that don’t understand that there are supposed to be three dots.
Heheh, I'm not particularly advocating for it.
I think we want ellipses, but in an ideal world we might want the unicode symbol "…" rather than "...". I'm not sure browsers let us do that.
Hmm, after editing to use the default font rather than the code block one, it's not clearly an improvement.

In any case, I agree it's important to have a ... type indication when we're cutting off text. I think we had a previous version of "Private messages" that had that feature, and it was really confusing in organizations where you had a lot of conversations with someone who has a long name.

I'll add on the process point that each change should be in its own commit with a commit (haven't checked whether this PR does so, just clarifying how best to communicate around code for whoever's reading).
